title: Morphology
description:
The study of the form and structure of organisms.
Example: Comparing the wings of bats and birds.

title: Comparative Anatomy
description:
The study of similarities and differences in the anatomy of organisms.
Example: Comparison of human and chimpanzee skeletons.

title: Homologous Structures
description:
Structures derived from a common ancestor but serving different functions.
Example: Forelimbs of humans and whales.

title: Analogous Structures
description:
Structures with similar functions but different evolutionary origins.
Example: Wings of insects and birds.

title: Histology
description:
The study of tissues under a microscope.
Example: Examination of epithelial tissue.

title: Epithelial Tissue
description:
Tissue that lines the surfaces of organs and structures.
Example: Skin epidermis.

title: Connective Tissue
description:
Tissue that supports, binds, or separates other tissues.
Example: Bone and blood.

title: Muscle Tissue
description:
Tissue capable of contracting to produce movement.
Example: Skeletal muscles in the arms.

title: Nervous Tissue
description:
Tissue responsible for transmitting electrical impulses.
Example: Neurons in the brain.

title: Exoskeleton
description:
An external skeleton supporting and protecting an organism.
Example: The shell of a crab.

title: Endoskeleton
description:
An internal skeleton supporting the body.
Example: The human skeleton.

title: Axial Skeleton
description:
The part of the skeleton consisting of the skull, spine, and ribcage.
Example: Human vertebral column.

title: Appendicular Skeleton
description:
The skeleton of limbs and girdles.
Example: Arms and legs in humans.

title: Cartilage
description:
Flexible connective tissue in the body.
Example: Cartilage in the ear.

title: Osteoblasts
description:
Cells that produce new bone material.
Example: Bone repair after a fracture.

title: Vertebrae
description:
The series of bones forming the spine.
Example: Cervical vertebrae in humans.

title: Amphibian Skeleton
description:
Skeleton adapted for life on land and water.
Example: Frog skeleton.

title: Bird Skeleton
description:
Lightweight skeleton adapted for flight.
Example: Hollow bones in pigeons.

title: Invertebrate Anatomy
description:
Study of internal and external structures of invertebrates.
Example: Anatomy of earthworms.

title: Vertebrate Anatomy
description:
Study of internal and external structures of vertebrates.
Example: Anatomy of fishes.

title: Muscle Fiber
description:
The basic unit of muscle tissue.
Example: Skeletal muscle fibers in arms.

title: Myofibrils
description:
Thread-like structures in muscle cells responsible for contraction.
Example: Actin and myosin filaments.

title: Cardiac Muscle
description:
Involuntary muscle tissue found in the heart.
Example: Heart muscles beating rhythmically.

title: Smooth Muscle
description:
Involuntary muscle tissue found in organs.
Example: Muscle in the stomach wall.

title: Skeletal Muscle
description:
Voluntary muscle tissue attached to bones.
Example: Biceps contracting to lift weight.

title: Neuron
description:
The basic unit of the nervous system.
Example: Nerve cells transmitting signals.

title: Axon
description:
The part of a neuron that carries electrical impulses.
Example: Axon of a motor neuron.

title: Synapse
description:
The gap between two neurons for signal transmission.
Example: Chemical transmission at the synapse.

title: Brainstem
description:
The part of the brain connecting to the spinal cord.
Example: Controls basic life functions like breathing.

title: Cerebrum
description:
The largest part of the brain controlling voluntary actions.
Example: Cerebrum for decision-making.

title: Cerebellum
description:
The brain region responsible for coordination and balance.
Example: Maintaining posture while walking.

title: Heart Chambers
description:
Compartments of the heart pumping blood.
Example: Four chambers in human hearts.

title: Arteries
description:
Blood vessels carrying oxygenated blood from the heart.
Example: The aorta.

title: Veins
description:
Blood vessels carrying deoxygenated blood to the heart.
Example: The vena cava.

title: Capillaries
description:
Small blood vessels where gas exchange occurs.
Example: Capillaries in lungs exchanging oxygen.

title: Hemoglobin
description:
Protein in red blood cells carrying oxygen.
Example: Hemoglobin binding oxygen in the lungs.

title: Lymphatic System
description:
System collecting and returning interstitial fluid to blood.
Example: Lymph nodes fighting infections.

title: Open Circulatory System
description:
Circulatory system where blood is not confined to vessels.
Example: Found in insects.

title: Closed Circulatory System
description:
Circulatory system where blood is confined to vessels.
Example: Found in vertebrates.

title: Respiratory System
description:
System responsible for gas exchange in organisms.
Example: Lungs in humans.

title: Gill
description:
Respiratory organ in aquatic animals.
Example: Fish gills extracting oxygen from water.

title: Tracheal System
description:
Network of tubes for respiration in insects.
Example: Found in grasshoppers.

title: Lung
description:
Respiratory organ in terrestrial vertebrates.
Example: Human lungs breathing air.

title: Diaphragm
description:
Muscle aiding in breathing in mammals.
Example: Diaphragm contracting during inhalation.

title: Spinal Cord
description:
Part of the central nervous system transmitting signals.
Example: Reflex actions controlled by the spinal cord.

title: Peripheral Nervous System
description:
Nervous system outside the brain and spinal cord.
Example: Nerves in arms and legs.

title: Sensory Neurons
description:
Neurons carrying signals from sense organs to the brain.
Example: Signals from the eye to the brain.

title: Motor Neurons
description:
Neurons carrying signals from the brain to muscles.
Example: Controlling hand movement.

title: Interneurons
description:
Neurons connecting sensory and motor neurons.
Example: Processing reflex actions.

title: Endocrine System
description:
System of glands secreting hormones.
Example: Pituitary gland regulating growth.

title: Excretory System
description:
System responsible for removing waste from the body.
Example: Kidneys filtering blood in humans.

title: Nephrons
description:
Functional units of the kidney.
Example: Nephrons filtering blood in mammals.

title: Urea
description:
Nitrogenous waste excreted by mammals.
Example: Urea in human urine.

title: Malpighian Tubules
description:
Excretory structures in insects.
Example: Malpighian tubules in grasshoppers.

title: Flame Cells
description:
Excretory structures in flatworms.
Example: Flame cells in planaria.

title: Homeostasis
description:
Maintenance of stable internal conditions.
Example: Regulation of body temperature in humans.

title: Metamorphosis
description:
Developmental transformation in animals.
Example: Caterpillars becoming butterflies.

title: Ectotherms
description:
Organisms relying on external sources for body heat.
Example: Reptiles basking in the sun.

title: Endotherms
description:
Organisms generating internal heat to regulate temperature.
Example: Birds maintaining constant body temperature.

title: Digestive System
description:
System breaking down food for nutrient absorption.
Example: Stomach and intestines in humans.

title: Alimentary Canal
description:
The whole passage food travels through the digestive system.
Example: Esophagus, stomach, and intestines.

title: Liver
description:
Organ producing bile and aiding in metabolism.
Example: Liver detoxifying substances in humans.

title: Pancreas
description:
Gland producing digestive enzymes and hormones.
Example: Insulin production by the pancreas.

title: Gills in Mollusks
description:
Respiratory organs in aquatic mollusks.
Example: Clams using gills to filter water.

title: Radial Symmetry
description:
Symmetry around a central axis.
Example: Starfish exhibiting radial symmetry.

title: Bilateral Symmetry
description:
Body divided into two identical halves.
Example: Humans with bilateral symmetry.

title: Asymmetry
description:
No specific symmetry in body structure.
Example: Sponges with asymmetrical bodies.

title: Notochord
description:
A flexible rod supporting the body in embryonic stages.
Example: Notochord in vertebrate embryos.

title: Coelom
description:
Body cavity housing internal organs.
Example: Coelom in earthworms.

title: Pseudocoelomates
description:
Animals with a body cavity not completely lined by mesoderm.
Example: Roundworms as pseudocoelomates.

title: Acoelomates
description:
Animals lacking a body cavity.
Example: Flatworms as acoelomates.

title: Amphibian Circulation
description:
Circulatory system with three heart chambers.
Example: Frogs with mixed blood circulation.

title: Reptilian Circulation
description:
Circulatory system with partially divided ventricles.
Example: Crocodiles with a four-chambered heart.

title: Bird Circulation
description:
Efficient double circulation with four heart chambers.
Example: Oxygenated blood supply in sparrows.

title: Gill Slits
description:
Openings for respiration in aquatic animals.
Example: Sharks with gill slits.

title: Spiracles
description:
Openings in arthropods for respiration.
Example: Spiracles in grasshoppers.

title: Larynx
description:
Voice box in vertebrates.
Example: Human larynx producing speech sounds.

title: Alveoli
description:
Tiny air sacs in lungs for gas exchange.
Example: Oxygen exchange in human alveoli.

title: Exocrine Glands
description:
Glands secreting substances via ducts.
Example: Sweat glands in the skin.

title: Endocrine Glands
description:
Ductless glands secreting hormones.
Example: Thyroid gland regulating metabolism.

title: Adrenal Glands
description:
Glands producing adrenaline and corticosteroids.
Example: Adrenal glands responding to stress.

title: Pituitary Gland
description:
Master gland controlling other glands.
Example: Secreting growth hormone.

title: Thyroid Gland
description:
Gland regulating metabolism.
Example: Thyroid secreting thyroxine.

title: Excretory Organs in Annelids
description:
Structures removing waste in segmented worms.
Example: Nephridia in earthworms.

title: Chitinous Exoskeleton
description:
External skeleton made of chitin in arthropods.
Example: Exoskeleton of crabs.

title: Segmentation
description:
Division of body into segments.
Example: Segments in earthworms.

title: Cephalization
description:
Development of a head region with sensory organs.
Example: Cephalization in flatworms.

title: Hydrostatic Skeleton
description:
Skeleton formed by fluid pressure.
Example: Hydrostatic skeleton in jellyfish.

title: Oviparous
description:
Animals laying eggs.
Example: Birds and reptiles as oviparous species.

title: Viviparous
description:
Animals giving live birth.
Example: Humans and mammals as viviparous species.

title: Ovoviviparous
description:
Animals with eggs hatching inside the body.
Example: Sharks as ovoviviparous species.

title: Plasma
description:
Liquid component of blood.
Example: Plasma transporting nutrients in humans.

title: Platelets
description:
Blood cells aiding in clotting.
Example: Platelets forming clots to stop bleeding.

title: Red Blood Cells
description:
Blood cells carrying oxygen.
Example: RBCs transporting oxygen via hemoglobin.

title: White Blood Cells
description:
Blood cells fighting infections.
Example: WBCs attacking pathogens.

title: Haversian Canal
description:
Microscopic tubes in bones carrying blood vessels.
Example: Haversian canals in compact bones.

title: Cartilaginous Fish
description:
Fish with skeletons made of cartilage.
Example: Sharks and rays.

title: Bony Fish
description:
Fish with skeletons made of bone.
Example: Salmon and trout.

title: Amniotic Egg
description:
Egg with a protective shell and membranes.
Example: Reptilian and bird eggs.

title: Placenta
description:
Organ connecting mother and fetus during pregnancy.
Example: Nutrient exchange in mammals.
